metadata./Title: Right juxtaposition of left atrial appendage combined with multiple cardiac malformations: A case report and review of literature
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Juxtaposition of the atrial appendages is an extremely rare congenital cardiac malformation. It is usually discovered incidentally during autopsy or surgery. This report aims to increase awareness of right juxtaposition 
of the left atrial appendage.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report a Chinese Han female aged 2 years and 10 months with recurrent lung infections 
after birth, who was diagnosed with congenital heart disease, corrected transposition of the great arteries, ventricular 
septal defect, and arterial ductus arteriosus at the local hospital and improved after the pulmonary artery banding 
procedure. The patient presented to our hospital with intermittent cough. During preoperative evaluation, a review 
of imaging data revealed a right juxtaposition of the left atrial appendage on enhanced computed tomography.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Right juxtaposition of the left atrial appendage is a rare congenital heart anomaly that often occurs 
in conjunction with complex cardiac malformations. Diagnosis requires a combination of imaging modalities 
to improve detection rates. Careful identification of cardiac structures during surgery is crucial, as alterations in cardiac 
anatomy may increase surgical risks. For instance, the opening of juxtaposed atrial appendages could be mistaken 
for an atrial septal defect.
Keywords  Juxtaposition of atrial appendages, Congenital heart disease, Case report
Background
The left atrial appendage (LAA) was previously consid ered a dormant embryonic remnant. However, recent 
studies have confirmed that the LAA is a structurally 
complex organ contributing to cardiac hemodynamic sta bility through its contractile properties and secretion of 
neurohormonal peptides. Electrical, structural, or func tional remodeling of the LAA may increase thrombosis risk [ 1]. The right atrial appendage (RAA) has been less 
extensively studied; although, it may be the origin of 
atrial fibrillation in some cases [2].
Juxtaposition of atrial appendages (JAA) is a rare con genital cardiac malformation, first defined by Dixon 
in 1954. In JAA, both atrial appendages are positioned 
either to the left or right of the great arteries and are 
usually associated with cyanotic congenital heart dis ease (CHD) [3]. A study involving 22 patients with 
JAA reported that it often occurs in conjunction with 
complex cardiac malformations [4]. JAA can be diag nosed by a variety of

Left juxtaposition of the right atrial appendage 
(LJRAA) is six times more common than right juxtapo sition of the left atrial appendage (RJLAA), with most 
previous reports focusing on LJRAA [6]. We present a 
rare case of RJLAA to enhance clinicians’ understanding 
of JAA, which is crucial for clinical diagnosis, treatment 
planning, and surgical strategy selection.
Case presentation
A 2-year-10-month-old Chinese Han female was admit ted to our hospital with intermittent cough. She denied 
chest pain, palpitations, or dyspnea. Physical examina tion on admission showed a temperature of 36.3  °C, 
pulse of 109 beats/minute, respiration rate of 28 breaths/
minute, and blood pressure of 81/56  mmHg. Ausculta tion revealed a hyperactive second heart sound in the 
pulmonary valve area and a grade III systolic murmur in 
the second intercostal space at the right and left sternal 
margins. The patient’s medical history included recur rent pneumonia, with no known family history of heart 
disease. She had been previously diagnosed with trans position of the great arteries (SLL type) and ventricular 
septal defect (perimembranous type) and had undergone pulmonary artery banding with regular postoperative 
follow-ups.

enhanced CT images revealed RJLAA, with the LAA 
positioned superior to the RAA. After thorough evalua tion, a corrective surgery for complex CHD was planned, 
including atrial switch, ventricular septal defect repair, 
removal of pulmonary artery banding, and arterial switch 
operation.
The surgery began with a median sternotomy, reveal ing severe pericardial adhesions and tissue edema. Intra operative findings confirmed abnormal cardiac structure: 
atrial situs solitus with RJLAA, L-looped ventricles, the 
aorta positioned anteriorly and to the left arising from 
the anatomical right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery 
posteriorly arising from the anatomical left ventricle.
The surgical procedure involved establishing cardio pulmonary bypass, followed by dissection of major ves sels and cardiac arrest induction. Key steps included 
coronary artery button excision and reimplantation, ven tricular septal defect repair, arterial switch operation, and 
complex intra-atrial baffle reconstruction.
Postoperatively, the heart initially resumed spontane ous beating. However, approximately 2 minutes later, 
ventricular tachycardia progressed to ventricular fibril lation. Despite immediate initiation of emergency meas ures, including extracorporeal membrane oxygenation 
for resuscitation, the patient could not be saved. The

Discussion
The atrial appendage is an accessory structure formed 
from the primitive atrium during the third week of the 
embryo. In most patients, LAA is finger-like and extends 
between the anterior and lateral walls of the left atrium, 
with its tip pointing anteriorly and superiorly [7]. RAA is 
a protruding part of the right atrium that is triangular in 
shape and has received less attention.
JAA is defined as the positioning of both atrial append ages on the same side of the aorta, each originating 
from its corresponding atrial cavity. In most cases, the 
appendages are located on the left side of the great arter ies; rarely, they are positioned on the right side. In some 
instances, one atrial appendage may be lobulated and 
appear partially juxtaposed [6]. Typically, in JAA, the jux taposed ectopic atrial appendage is superior to the nor mal atrial appendage. For example, in LJRAA, the RAA 
originates in the right atrium, posterior to the great arter ies, and extends over the left atrium to the left, above the 
LAA.
This malformation was first reported by Birmingham 
in 1893, but the term “juxtaposition of the atrial append ages” was coined by Dixon in 1954. The mechanism of 
its formation remains unclear. One theory suggests that 
LJRAA results from reduced twisting of the primitive 
cardiac tube, while RJLAA is due to excessive twisting [6].JAA classification is based on the position of the atrial 
appendage relative to the great vessels, as proposed by 
Dixon et al. [8].Van Praagh et al. suggested using a com bination of positional and morphological categoriza tion to more accurately characterize JAA, especially in 
patients with situs inversus or heterotaxy syndromes [6].
Van Praagh noted a high correlation between JAA and 
complex CHD [6]. A large retrospective echocardio graphic study found that LJRAA was commonly associ ated with tricuspid atresia, transposition of the great 
arteries (TGA), and double outlet right ventricle. RJLAA 
was more likely to occur with obstructive left heart dis ease. Occasionally, JAA has been reported in combina tion with simple or uncomplicated cardiac malformations 
[9].
Our case aligns with these patterns, presenting RJLAA 
in conjunction with multiple cardiac malformations, 
including TGA, ventricular septal defect, patent ductus 
arteriosus, mild to moderate tricuspid regurgitation, and 
patent foramen ovale (PFO).
Reports of JAA are rare, and such reports are even 
rarer because of the even lower incidence of RJLAA. This 
article summarizes the published reports on the subject 
(Table 1).
Diagnosis of JAA can be challenging due to its rar ity and lack of clinical awareness. Electrocardiograms in 
JAA patients typically show normal P waves, suggesting 
that sinus node position is unaffected despite the abnor mal atrial appendage morphology [9].Chest X-rays often

reveal a prominent cardiac margin on the side of juxtapo sition [6].
In diagnosing JAA using transthoracic echocardiog raphy, the LAA is more clearly visible in four-chamber 
views, which can be a clue for suspected JAA. Addition ally, abnormalities in the horizontal direction of the atrial 
septum are often present in JAA, providing another diag nostic hint.
In this population, JAA is often not detected by pre operative echocardiography, is accidentally detected at 
the time of surgery, and is only confirmed postopera tively by retrospective analysis of the echocardiographic 
images.2D echocardiography is not a good diagnostic 
method in this special population with a high rate of 
missed diagnoses, and should be used in combination 
with other imaging techniques to improve the accuracy 
of the diagnosis.
Communication may exist in the juxtaposed atrial 
appendages. Karac et al. reported a case of a patient with 
a diagnosis of ASD and pulmonary stenosis in which jux taposition of the LAA and a tunnel-like passage between 
the LAA and the morphologic right atrium were acciden tally detected during surgery [11]. In a case of LJRAA, 
a tunnel between the atria was also identified, and the 
shunt channel was surgically closed and the patient’s 
symptoms improved postoperatively [12]. This may sug gest that once a fusion of the atrial appendages has been 
identified, it is important to consider ruling out the pos sibility of a channel between the atrial appendages. Given 
the difficulty of detecting a channel between the atrial 
appendages using conventional transthoracic echocardi ography or CT, the presence of such a luminal connec tion should be confirmed, if necessary, by enhanced CT 
or angiography.
Recent studies have suggested that prophylactic antico agulation in patients with juxtaposed atrial appendages 
following Fontan surgery may be beneficial in reducing 
the risk of thrombosis [10]. In the presence of cardiac 
hemodynamic disturbances, LAA is indeed prone to 
thrombus formation, but there is currently too little evi dence in this regard, and considering that patients with 
JAA tend to have a more complex cardiac structure, how 
to weigh the benefits and risks of prophylactic anticoagu lation needs to be further explored in more studies.
JAA may increase postoperative risk in single ventri cle palliation. In a series of 22 JAA cases reported by Lai 
et  al., 11 patients underwent single ventricle palliation 
with a mortality rate of 55%, while no deaths occurred 
among 8 patients who underwent biventricular repair [4].
The presence of JAA can affect surgical planning and 
execution due to altered cardiac anatomy. Abnormal 
septal orientation and reduced atrial volume may occur, 
necessitating more careful identification and handling of cardiac structures during surgery to avoid unex pected complications.
For example, in interventional procedures, the 
echocardiogram shows normal posterior septal align ment in JAA, but the anterior septal alignment is 
abnormally oriented parallel to the anterior chest wall, 
so the location of the blocker should be noted on imag ing when intervening on ASD located anteriorly [6 ]. 
During cardiac catheterization procedures in patients 
with LJRAA, particularly for atrial septal defect or pat ent foramen ovale closure, the catheter or guidewire 
may inadvertently enter the juxtaposed RAA through 
the ASD/PFO. This can complicate access to the left 
atrium and pulmonary veins via the interatrial septum.
TGA often requires balloon septostomy, and in the 
presence of LJRAA, it is not clear to see the position of 
the inflatable balloon catheter, which may easily cause 
injury to the base of the atrial appendage to tear it [13].
Failure to recognize a JAA during surgery makes 
it easy to treat a juxtaposed atrial appendage orifice 
mistakenly as an ASD. Complex CHD, represented 
by TGA, with JAA makes both septal septotomy and 
atrial switching procedures technically more difficult 
[6]. Recognizing JAA abnormalities in advance allows 
for thorough preparation and planning during intuba tion and venting sessions of cardiac extracorporeal cir culatory procedures (for example, Senning and Fontan 
operations in extracardial tunnels), avoiding intraop erative surprises [5 ].
Conclusion
We report a case of RJLAA combined with multiple 
complex cardiac malformations. This case highlights 
the importance of understanding the definition, forma tion mechanism, classification, key diagnostic points, 
and impact on treatment and surgical approaches 
for this rare type of CHD. Our report aims to deepen 
understanding of this uncommon condition and pro vide reference for clinicians in developing diagnostic 
and therapeutic protocols for similar cases.
